titles.title: Making technical corrections in the Rules of the House of Representatives.

action.text: Referred to the House Committee on Rules.
Committee Consideration and Mark-up Session Held.

calendar.text: Ordered to be Reported (Amended) by Voice Vote.

action.text: Reported (Amended) by the Committee on Rules. H. Rept. 104-340.

calendar.text: Placed on the House Calendar, Calendar No. 122.

action.text: Mr. Dreier asked unanimous consent that it be in order without intervening motion to consider H. Res. 254; that the amendment recommended by the Committee on Rules be considered as adopted; that the previous question be considered as ordererd on the resolution; only the amendment offered by the Chairman of the Rules Committee or his designee is permitted; and debate will be limited to one hour. Agreed to without objection.
Considered pursuant to a previous agreement.
DEBATE - The House proceeded with one hour of debate.
The previous question was ordered pursuant to a previous order of the House.

vote.text: On agreeing to the resolution Agreed to by voice vote.

action.text: Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

bill.summary: 11/30/1995--Passed House amended. Makes technical and conforming corrections in the Rules of the House of Representatives concerning the Journal (of congressional proceedings); the Office of the Inspector General; the Committee on National Security; the Committee on Small Business; special oversight functions of the Committee on Resources and the Committee on Commerce; the three-day layover for filing of supplemental, minority, or additional views, committee reports, appropriations hearings and reports, conference reports, and Senate amendments to measures reported in disagreement; committee broadcast rules; committee staffs; the Corrections Calendar; privilege for measures reported by the Committee on Ways and Means; unfunded mandate reform; and the gift rule ( excludes from gifts banned under such rule donations of products from the Member's State that are intended primarily for promotional purposes such as display or free distribution and that are of minimal value to any individual recipient; and items of nominal value such as a greeting card, baseball cap, or a T-shirt).
